org.jscripter.emu.gc
Class GCDOM

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      org.jscripter.emu.gc.GC
          org.jscripter.emu.gc.GCDOM

public class GCDOM
extends GC

An internal base class of DOM object visitors emulating garbage collection based finalization in JavaScript for DOM implementations.

This class is only used internally by JS re-compiler implementations.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
This class is only loaded and resolved by re-compiler implementations.

appendChild

public static final js.user.JsNode appendChild(js.user.JsNode p,
                                               js.user.JsNode c)

Internally adds a node to the document tree by appending it to the JsNode.childNodes array of this node with finalization emulation.

This method adds the node c to the document, inserting it as the last child of this node. If c is already in the document tree, it is removed from the tree and then reinserted at its new location. If c is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, all its children are appended, in order, to the end of this node's JsNode.childNodes array. Note that a node from (or created by) one document cannot be inserted into a different document. That is, the JsNode.ownerDocument property of c must be the same as the JsNode.ownerDocument property of this node.

Parameters:
p - The current node.
c - The node to be inserted into the document. If the node is of JsDocumentFragment, it is not directly inserted, but each of its children are.
Returns:
The node that was added.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or c is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if the JsNode.ownerDocument property of c is not the same as the JsNode.ownerDocument property of this node, or the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow children to be appended, or the node being appended is already part of the document tree, and its parent is read-only and does not allow children to be removed. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
removeChild(JsNode, JsNode), Nodes.appendChild(JsNode, JsNode), JsNode.appendChild(JsNode)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

removeChild

public static final js.user.JsNode removeChild(js.user.JsNode p,
                                               js.user.JsNode c)

Internally removes and returns the specified child node from the document tree with finalization emulation.

This method removes the specified child from the JsNode.childNodes array of this node. It is an error to call this method with a node that is not a child. This method returns the c node after removing it. c continues to be a valid node and may be reinserted into the document later.

Parameters:
p - The current node.
c - The child node to remove.
Returns:
The node that was removed.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow children to be removed, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if c is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
appendChild(JsNode, JsNode), Nodes.removeChild(JsNode, JsNode), JsNode.removeChild(JsNode)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

insertAdjacentHTML

public static final void insertAdjacentHTML(js.user.JsNode node,
                                            java.lang.String where,
                                            java.lang.String html)

Internally inserts the given HTML text into the element at the location with finalization emulation.

This method is IE-specific.

Parameters:
node - The current node.
where - A string that specifies where to insert the HTML text, using one of the following values:
  • "beforeBegin": Inserts html immediately before the object.
  • "afterBegin": Inserts html after the start of the object but before all other content in the object.
  • "beforeEnd": Inserts html immediately before the end of the object but after all other content in the object.
  • "afterEnd": Inserts html immediately after the end of the object.
html - A string that specifies the HTML text to insert. The string can be a combination of text and HTML tags. This must be well-formed, valid HTML or this method will fail.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Nodes.insertAdjacentHTML(JsNode, String, String), JsNode.insertAdjacentHTML(String, String)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

insertBefore

public static final js.user.JsNode insertBefore(js.user.JsNode node,
                                                js.user.JsNode newChild,
                                                js.user.JsNode refChild)

Internally inserts a node into the current document tree immediately before the specified child node with finalization emulation.

This method inserts the node newChild into the document tree as a child of this node. The new node is positioned within this node's JsNode.childNodes array so that it comes immediately before the refChild node. If refChild is null, newChild is inserted at the end of JsNode.childNodes, just as with the JsNode.appendChild(JsNode) method. Note that it is illegal to call this method with a refChild that is not a child of this node.

If the node being inserted is already in the tree, it is removed and reinserted at its new location.

If newChild is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, each of its children is inserted, in order, at the specified location.

Parameters:
node - The current node.
newChild - The node to be inserted into the document. If the node is of JsDocumentFragment, it is not directly inserted, but each of its children are.
refChild - The child of this node before which newChild is to be inserted. If this argument is null, newChild is inserted as the last child of this node.
Returns:
The node that was inserted.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or newChild is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if the JsNode.ownerDocument property of newChild is not the same as the JsNode.ownerDocument property of this node, the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow insertion, or the parent of newChild is read-only and does not allow deletion, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if refChild is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Nodes.insertBefore(JsNode, JsNode, JsNode), JsNode.insertBefore(JsNode, JsNode)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

replaceChild

public static final js.user.JsNode replaceChild(js.user.JsNode node,
                                                js.user.JsNode newChild,
                                                js.user.JsNode oldChild)

Internally removes and returns the specified child node from the document tree, replacing it with another node with finalization emulation.

This method replaces one node of the document tree with another. oldChild is the node to be replaced and must be a child of this node. newChild is the node that takes its place in the JsNode.childNodes array of this node.

If newChild is already part of the document, it is first removed from the document before being reinserted at its new position.

If newChild is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, each of its children is inserted, in order, at the position formerly occupied by oldChild.

Parameters:
node - The current node.
newChild - The replacement node.
oldChild - The node to be replaced.
Returns:
The node that was removed from the document and replaced.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or newChild is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if newChild and this node have different values for JsNode.ownerDocument property, the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow replacement, or newChild is the child of a node that does not allow removals, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if oldChild is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsNode.replaceChild(JsNode, JsNode)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

addEventListener

public static final void addEventListener(js.dom.EventTarget et,
                                          java.lang.String type,
                                          js.core.JsFunction<?> listener,
                                          java.lang.Boolean useCapture)

Internally adds an event handler function to the set of event handlers for this element with finalization emulation support. This is a DOM-standard method supported by all modern browsers except IE.

This method adds the specified event listener function to the set of listeners registered on this node to handle events of the specified type. If useCapture is true, the listener is registered as a capturing event listener. If useCapture is false, it is registered as a normal event listener.

This method may be called multiple times to register multiple event handlers for the same type of event on the same node. Note, however, that the DOM Specification makes no guarantees about the order in which multiple event handlers are invoked.

If the same event listener function is registered twice on the same node with the same type and useCapture arguments, the second registration is simply ignored. If a new event listener is registered on this node while an event is being handled at this node, the new event listener is not invoked for that event.

When a node is duplicated with JsNode.cloneNode(Boolean) or JsDocument.importNode(JsNode, Boolean), the event listeners registered for the original node are not copied.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsDocument and JsWindow objects.

Parameters:
et - The current event target.
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked.
listener - The event listener function that is invoked when an event of the specified type is dispatched to this node. When invoked, the listener function is passed an JsEvent object and is invoked as a method of the node on which it is registered.
useCapture - If true, the specified listener is to be invoked only during the capturing phase of event propagation. The more common value of false means that the listener is not invoked during the capturing phase but instead is invoked when this node is the actual event target or when the event bubbles up to this node from its original target.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
attachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction), removeEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean), EventTarget.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsDocument.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsWindow.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

removeEventListener

public static final void removeEventListener(js.dom.EventTarget et,
                                             java.lang.String type,
                                             js.core.JsFunction<?> listener,
                                             java.lang.Boolean useCapture)

Internally removes an event handler function from the set of handlers for this element with finalization emulation support. This is a standard DOM method implemented by all modern browsers except IE.

This method removes the specified event listener function. The type and useCapture arguments must be the same as they are in the corresponding call to addEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean). If no event listener is found that matches the specified arguments, this method does nothing.

Once an event listener function has been removed by this method, it will no longer be invoked for the specified type of event on this node. This is true even if the event listener is removed by another event listener registered for the same type of event on the same node.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsDocument and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
et - The current event target.
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be deleted.
listener - The event listener function that is to be removed.
useCapture - true if a capturing event listener is to be removed; false if a normal event listener is to be removed.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
detachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction), addEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean), EventTarget.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsDocument.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsWindow.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

attachEvent

public static final void attachEvent(js.dom.EventTarget et,
                                     java.lang.String type,
                                     js.core.JsFunction<?> listener)

Internally adds an event handler function to the set of handlers for this element with finalization emulation support. This is the IE-specific alternative to addEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean).

This method is an IE-specific event registration method. It serves the same purpose as the standard addEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean) method, which IE does not support, but is different from that function in several important ways:

  • Since the IE event model does not support event capturing, this method and detachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction) expect only two arguments: the event type and the handler function.
  • The event handler names passed to the IE methods should include the "on" prefix.
  • Functions registered with this method are invoked with no JsEvent JsWindow.event property of JsWindow.window object.
  • Functions registered with this method are invoked as global functions, rather than as methods of the node on which the event occurred. That is, when an event handler registered with this method executes, the this keyword refers to JsWindow.window object, not to the event's target node.
  • This method allows the same event handler function to be registered more than once. When an event of the specified type occurs, the registered function is invoked as many times as it is registered.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsDocument and JsWindow objects.

Parameters:
et - The current event target.
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked, with a leading "on" prefix.
listener - The event listener function that is invoked when an event of the specified type is dispatched to this node. This function is not passed any JsWindow.event property of the JsWindow object.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
addEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean), detachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction), EventTarget.attachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsDocument.attachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsWindow.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.

detachEvent

public static final void detachEvent(js.dom.EventTarget et,
                                     java.lang.String type,
                                     js.core.JsFunction<?> listener)

Internally removes an event handler function from this element with finalization emulation support. This is the IE-specific alternative to the standard removeEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean) method.

This method undoes the event handler function registration performed by the attachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction) method. It is the IE-specific analog to the standard removeEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean). To remove an event handler function for a node, simply invoke this method with the same arguments you originally passed to attachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction).

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsDocument and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
et - The current event target.
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked, with a leading "on" prefix.
listener - The event listener function that is to be removed.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
removeEventListener(EventTarget, String, JsFunction, Boolean), attachEvent(EventTarget, String, JsFunction), EventTarget.detachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsDocument.detachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsWindow.detachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on end-users directly using this method.
